findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract modifies the state of certain variables without checking if their current state is equal to the one given as an argument, resulting in redundant storage writes.

findings.title: FSA - Fixed Swap Address
findings.description: The swap address is assigned once and cannot be changed, which may prevent the contract from migrating to a new liquidity pool pair or decentralized exchange.

findings.title: MEE - Missing Events Emission
findings.description: The contract performs actions and state mutations from external methods that do not result in the emission of events.

findings.title: PTRP - Potential Transfer Revert Propagation
findings.description: The contract sends funds to a `marketingWallet` as part of the transfer flow. If the address belongs to a contract then it may revert from incoming payment, propagating the error to the token’s contract and reverting the transfer.

findings.title: DDP - Decimal Division Precision
findings.description: Division of decimal (fixed point) numbers can result in rounding errors due to the way that division is implemented in Solidity, leading to issues with precise calculations with decimal numbers.

findings.title: RSML - Redundant SafeMath Library
findings.description: The usage of the SafeMath library adds complexity, overhead and increases gas consumption unnecessarily since Solidity versions greater than or equal to 0.8.0 provide native functionality for arithmetic operations.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract declares state variables that are initialized once in the constructor and are not modified afterwards. Declaring them as immutable can save gas by allowing the Solidity compiler to make certain optimizations.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure they cannot be changed after being set, which decreases gas consumption.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: Non-conformance to Solidity naming conventions can lead to decreased readability and maintainability of the codebase.

findings.title: L05 - Unused State Variable
findings.description: An unused state variable is a state variable that is declared in the contract, but is never used in any of the contract's functions.

findings.title: L16 - Validate Variable Setters
findings.description: The contract performs operations on variables configured with user-supplied input without proper checks for zero values, leading to potential problems and unexpected behavior.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version (i.e., any version that is a higher minor or patch version) can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.

findings.title: L20 - Succeeded Transfer Check
findings.description: According to the ERC20 specification, the transfer methods should be checked if the result is successful. Otherwise, the contract may wrongly assume that the transfer has been established.
